titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jennie Thomas, Archivist

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-10-02T11:41-0400

physdesc.extent: (2 records cartons, 1 Hollinger box, 1 oversize box, 1 shared flat file drawer)

did.abstract: The Doug Fieger Papers span the years 1978 to 2010, with the bulk of the papers dating between 1979 and 1981. The collection provides rich documentation of the power pop group, The Knack. The majority of the articles and clippings, audiovisual materials, business files, fan club documents, lyrics, and posters in the collection follow the career of the Knack from their smash hit in 1979, "My Sharona," to the revitalization of the song in 1994 in the film Reality Bites. The personal files and publications in the collection more accurately portray Fieger's interest in the lives of his family, friends, and colleagues, the role of Nick that he played on TV's Roseanne, and his love of vintage guitars. The collection highlights the life of a rock band from obscurity to superstardom and back again. It also provides perspective into Fieger's creative process, his career with and without the Knack, and his personal interests.
did.langmaterial: Collection is predominantly in English. Materials in Spanish are identified at the file or item level, as appropriate.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Douglas Lars Fieger is born in Oak Park, Mich.
Fieger picks up the guitar and begins playing with John Coury.
Fieger and Coury form the group Sky and are managed by the owner of the Grande Ballroom, Detroit.
Jimmy Miller signs Sky.
Sky records their first album at Olympic Studios for RCA Records.

eventgrp.event: Fieger meets Bruce Gary (Knack's first drummer).

chronitem.event: Feiger and Gary meet Berton Averre (lead guitar/backing vocals/keyboards for the Knack).
Fieger plays bass for a short time in the German progressive rock band Triumvirat.
Meets last member of the Knack, Prescott Niles (bass), a week before the band's first show.
Capitol Records wins bidding war for the Knack against 12 other record companies.
"My Sharona," from the album Get the Knack, spends six weeks on Billboard's Hot 100.
Album ...But the Little Girls Understand is released.
Album Round Trip is released.
The Knack breaks up.
The Knack regroups to tour.

eventgrp.event: Billy Ward replaces Bruce Gary on drums.
Don Was produces album <title render="italic">Serious Fun</title> for the Knack.

chronitem.event: Popularity of "My Sharona" is revived through use in the film Reality Bites.
Knack performs to capacity at the Viper Room.
Knack performs on two tribute albums: Come and Get It: A Tribute to Badfinger and One Step Up/Two Steps Back: The Songs of Bruce Springsteen.
Album Zoom is released on Rhino Records.
Fieger releases solo album First Things First.

eventgrp.event: Album <title render="italic">Normal As The Next Guy</title> is released.
Laserdisc <title render="italic">Live at the Rock 'n' Roll Funhouse</title> is released.

chronitem.event: Bruce Gary dies of lymphoma.
Fieger dies after battling cancer for many years.

bioghist.p: Doug Fieger was best known as the lead singer of the Knack and co-writer with guitarist Berton Averre of the group's 1979 number one hit "My Sharona." His colorful and storied career went beyond that hit recording and the band, however, with an array of escapades in the music industry dating back to when he was a young teen with Jeff Beck, Bobby Keys, Jim Price, Pete Townsend, Traffic, and the Plastic Ono Band's Alan White, and a more serious side, including production work and interactions with Roy Orbison, Ringo Starr, and Was Not Was, among others.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Patrons must sign the Acknowledgment of Legal Responsibility and Privacy Rights statement on the Researcher Registration form before using this collection. Consult the Library and Archives in advance of your visit to ensure access to these materials is available.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: 45 rpm records, books, magazines, and concert programs in this collection have been transferred to the library. Please search for the "Doug Fieger Papers" in the library catalog for a list of donated titles. If you are unable to find what you are looking for, consult the Library and Archives staff to ensure these materials are available.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc. For more information, please consult the staff of the Library and Archives.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Jennie Thomas, Archivist. Completed October 8, 2010. Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS and local processing manual.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The Doug Fieger Papers were received by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc. as gifts from his sister Beth Falkenstein on September 3, 2010 and April 14, 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Doug Fieger Papers, Library and Archives, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.

did.unittitle: Series I: Articles, Clippings, and Photocopies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I: Articles, Clippings, and Photocopies pertains primarily to Fieger's work in The Knack and contains magazine and newspaper articles from all over the United States. The series is arranged chronologically by decade, except for those materials that had been previously compiled into smaller date spans by Beth Falkenstein or The Knack's management company.

did.unittitle: Knack, ...but the little girls understand ad from New Musical Express
Knack, Round Trip ad from Billboard magazine

Creem magazine front and back cover
Memorials to Fieger and Bruce Gary
Photocopy of photograph of Knack (Averre, Fieger, Ward, Niles) by Steve Granitz

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II: Business Files contains documents related to The Knack's album releases, promotions, and tours, as well as Doug Fieger's contracts and correspondence. The Series is broken down into six subseries: Albums, contracts, correspondence, miscellaneous, promotional materials, and tours and performances. The subseries are organized chronologically, with undated material at the end of each.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries 4: Miscellaneous includes documentation from the National Academy of Songwriters, interviews, the 1994 release of Reality Bites, scripts from the television show Roseanne, a newsletter from Capitol Records, and more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III: Fan Clubs contains newsletters and promotional advertisements for the Knack International Fan Club and the Knack Fan Club. The Series is chronological with undated material located at the end.

did.unittitle: The Knack fan clubs newsletter ( Knack Knews)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Lyrics contains handwritten and typed song lyrics and chord charts, as well as published sheet music for The Knack. Songs from the album Round Trip are featured prominently. Of note is a manuscript for the song "Don't Look Back," written by Bruce Springsteen. In 1979, The Knack recorded Bruce Springsteen's unreleased song, which remained an unissued studio track in the Capital vaults until the 1991 Retrospective. The track was later released again on the 1997 Capital Records' Springsteen tribute double CD Two Steps Forward, One Step Back. The Knack's "Don't Look Back" is the only released version of this Springsteen chestnut. In recording the song, the band increased the tempo and modified some of the lyrics. This series is organized chronologically undated material arranged alphabetically at the end.

did.unittitle: Handwritten and published sheet music and lyrics
Typed lyrics for Round Trip album
Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" [handwritten by Fieger]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: These appear to a photocopy of the lyrics, handwritten by Bruce Springsteen in a spiral bound notebook.

did.unittitle: Handwritten lyrics for 3rd album, Round Trip

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V: Personal Files contains articles, clippings, and other publications related to some of Fieger's personal interests, family, and friends, including his brother Geoff's political career, Was Not Was, Aerosmith, the Rubber City Rebels, Frank Zappa, the Troubadour, and Charlie Bishop. The Series is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Aerosmith's Get a Grip Tour, Glen Helen Blockbuster Pavilion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI: Posters includes promotional posters and a LP flat related to The Knack. The Series is arranged chronologically. Materials are stored out of sequence due to size and condition concerns.
